title: MSP trooper dragged by vehicle during East Boston stop
author: Samantha Genzer
bullets: A New Hampshire man, Binit Bikram Shah, was arrested after dragging a Massachusetts State Police trooper during a traffic stop.
The incident occurred near Central Square and Meridian Street in East Boston around 2:30 a.m.; the trooper was hospitalized.
Shah faces multiple charges, including assault and driving under the influence; an arrest warrant is being sought in East Boston.

title: Here’s why readers support voter ID laws, even as some take issue with SAVE America Act
author: Abby Patkin
bullets: The SAVE America Act requires voters to show proof of citizenship and photo ID for federal elections.
Massachusetts officials criticize the bill, fearing it might disenfranchise voters lacking necessary documentation.
Boston.com readers are divided; some support voter ID laws while others express concerns over voter suppression.

title: Mack Hollins fell just short of a stat worth $400K in incentives. The Patriots paid it anyway.
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: Mack Hollins missed his 50-catch incentive for $400K due to injury, ending the season with 46 catches.
Despite missing the benchmark, the Patriots awarded Hollins the $400K by adding it as a signing bonus.
Hollins led the Patriots in receiving yards during postseason and is signed for $4.3 million next season.

title: Why I’m running the Boston Marathon for charity after 9/11 — and what it means to me
author: Autumn Sloboda
bullets: Matt Marino, 48, runs the 2026 Boston Marathon to raise funds for the Webb Norden Foundation.
The Webb Norden Foundation, founded by Boston bombing survivors, aids children and young adults through traumatic events.
Marino connects with the cause due to personal trauma from witnessing 9/11, enhancing his marathon purpose.

title: Treated at Mass. Eye and Ear as a teen, she’s now running the Boston Marathon to give back
author: Autumn Sloboda
bullets: Mary Ellen Burt, 37, from Chelmsford, is running the 2026 Boston Marathon to support Mass Eye and Ear.
Burt underwent surgery for sinus and septum issues as a teenager at Mass Eye and Ear.
She aims to raise funds for Mass Eye and Ear, praising their care and mission for sensory and head conditions.

title: New Mass. and Cass recommendations could mark major shift in strategy
author: Ross Cristantiello
bullets: Boston leaders recommend expanding police and case manager units and creating a 'specialty court' for public drug use cases.
The proposals suggest shifting from harm reduction strategies, focusing on tougher approaches to address addiction and homelessness issues.
Boston city officials consider these recommendations a step toward coordinated solutions with community partners and public safety initiatives.

title: Massachusetts is 1 of 4 states that lost private-sector jobs over the last five years
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: Massachusetts lost 24,000 private-sector jobs from January 2020 to March 2025, a 0.74% decrease.
The state's GDP growth lagged behind the national average since 2022, affecting economic competitiveness.
Rising costs and lower job growth push residents to other states with better economic opportunities.

title: What is happening with the Central Square sign?
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: The Central Square sign in Cambridge was removed for repairs after being hit with graffiti.
Originally a Blockbuster sign, it was redesigned in 2018 to feature a rainbow symbolizing the LGBTQ+ community.
The sign will be reinstalled next week, with a celebratory party planned on March 13, featuring music and drinks.

title: Lifelong skiers say this New England ski resort is among the best in the U.S., according to Travel + Leisure
author: Kristi Palma
bullets: Killington Ski Resort in Vermont made Travel + Leisure's list of top 15 ski resorts in the U.S.
Killington offers 155 trails, 22 lifts, and spans 1,509 acres across six peaks, known as 'The Beast of the East.'
Killington Resort is recognized for both early openings and remaining open until June, offering diverse terrain experiences.

title: Dine Out Boston: What’s new, best deals, and best meals for winter 2026
author: Katelyn Umholtz
bullets: Dine Out Boston runs from February 22 to March 7, featuring 140 restaurants offering prix fixe lunch and dinner menus.
Participating restaurants, including Michelin-recognized spots, offer lunch for $27-$36 and dinner for $38-$55 across various cuisines.
New additions include The Block at Woods Hill, with farm-to-table offerings, and Nowon, known for its Korean-American street food.
